newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: N.Korea to top Japan minister's agenda in Seoul.
newsitem.headline: N.Korea to top Japan minister's agenda in Seoul.

text.p: A three-day visit to Seoul by Japan's defense minister is expected to focus on regional security as concern mounts over a possible military threat by North Korea, South Korean officials said on Sunday.

The South Korean National Defence Ministry said Fumio Kyuma and his counterpart, Kim Dong-jin, on Monday would discuss "the current situation on the Korean peninsula and security in the region along with ways to enhance cooperation between the two militaries".

A top Pyongyang defector was quoted last week as saying North Korea poses a threat to the south and to Japan. North Korean leaders have been growing increasingly desperate as their country slides into famine.
Japanese parliamentary sources said the ministers were expected to discuss in detail North Korea's war footing, especially its long-range missiles.

On April 14, Japanese Foreign Minister Yukihiko Ikeda told parliament there were unconfirmed reports that North Korea may have deployed Rodong-1 ballistic missiles, capable of hitting all parts of Japan.

"It is not that we confirmed this," Ikeda said, "but there are reports that (North Korea) has developed missiles with a range of more than 1,000 km (625 miles). There are certain reports that some of them have been deployed."
It was the first time a Japanese government official commented publicly on the possibility that North Korea may have completed development of the Rodong-1 missile.

To top the threat, Pyongyang's top defector, Hwang Jang-yop, who arrived in Seoul last Sunday, was quoted on Tuesday in a local daily as saying North Korea could turn the capitalist South into a "sea of flames" and scorch Japan in a nuclear attack if the United States tried to intervene.
Hwang's report, published in the Chosun Ilbo, did not make it clear whether the North already possessed nuclear weapons.

The United Nations' nuclear watch dog, the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), has never been able to confirm whether the North has a nuclear device, but insists it has fissionable material it is not owning up to. The North has refused inspectors the right to check its atomic sites.
A South Korean defence ministry spokesman told Reuters that politics would not be part of the visiting Kyuma's agenda.
But, there is still simmering resentment against Japan, which occupied the Korean peninsula for 35 years until 1945.
South Korean women who were forced into sexual slavery by the Japanese army during World War Two and referred to as "comfort women" are still demanding an official apology from Tokyo.
And ownership of a scattering of rocky islets off South Korea's east coast is another thorny issue.
Kyuma's visit follows the docking by Japanese warships last September in the southern port of Pusan -- the first such docking since World War Two.
That visit was meant as a good will gesture between the two countries, but it sparked criticism by anti-Japanese groups.
